What's an /fa/ martial art to learn? Preferably one with lower chance of CTE from practicing it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17430886
muay thai
capoeira
judo
taekwondo
sanda (prob unavailable in ur area, but look for a nearby gym where they offer classes in it anyway)
fencing
boxing

any functional martial art/combat sport practiced at a high level looks good if u understand it, which u will if u practice one or more for long enough.

anyways, as someone w/ about 6 years in total of training in martial arts, i can tell u that practicing one for the sake of form is dumb. u'll find urself learning an art w/ fancy moves, prob at a tma school (which will most likely be shit and produce wimps who can't fight their way out of a wet paper bag), possibly for years, and still not be equipped w/ the necessary skills to defend urself physically (speaking from experience).

u may never have to use those skills in a real life altercation, but on the off chance u do, u're fucked. this is why any martial artist worth their weight in salt will tell u that function is the most important thing to select for in practicing a given martial art, and that means training at a gym that produces capable fighters. and from there, once u've had enough years of training under ur belt, form should follow function and u'll get good enough at ur particular skillset that u make it look effay, as w/ any other skill.

pic rel is a flowchart to get u started on ur journey.

>then out of nowhere it just collapses and i gain almost all of it back
you're plateauing. everyone has a weight where they plateau - for me it's 105lbs.
>buy digital scale for 20 buckaroos
>avoid shocking your body too early
>incrementally stagger down your calorie deficit over a week
>recoup calories within 2-3 days so that your body doesn't think you're going into starvation mode
>repeat lowering plateau threshold
my original plateau was 106lbs last year, took 4 months to drop it down to 103-104lbs

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17429625
Running is easier if you have a specific goal imo. I have tried doing it before (lots of times) by just jumping on a treadmill and going for a set amount of time. It was always fuckin awful and felt like torture. A few weeks ago I downloaded a couch to 5K app and have been running 3-4 times a week on the provided plan and have found it much easier. I can easily see how much I've improved over these past weeks. I've also begun to record my distance and time on my phone so I can track improvement. As someone that has never been good at running it has helped me a lot. Lurking the /roon/ threads on /fit/has also helped. I have learned so much. Running isn't something anyone is good at at first. You gotta take it slow, have lots of rest days and stop if you're feeling any pain. Only once you've done it for a while can you increase how frequently you run.

You should definitely give it another shot after doing some research and picking a plan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17431138
Cardio workouts and HIIT get the best results. Daily run is always good for maintenance, but it doesn't sound like you're pairing it with proper diet.
Don't do keto. OMAD is hardly necessary, if you've lost weight but still have flab you've probably fucked your metabolism cause it's trying to store fat for the lack of sustenance you're giving it. Generally, you should eat at least be eating 2 meals a day, but SMALL meals with high nutritional value. I know /thin/ says starve yourself, and it's good to exercise self control to stop unnecessary snacking, but if you're really hungry, it's better to eat one or two rice crackers and maybe some almonds than to not have anything at all. Also eating in a small window of time is better than OMAD. So say 9 AM to 7 PM is your window to have 2-3 meals, with some light snacking when you're starting to get hunger pains. If you get hungry after 7PM, then you should go to sleep as soon as possible. That's another thing, if your sleep schedule is fucked, you're gonna struggle to shed pounds.
But yeah OMAD helps weight loss but not fat loss which will probably explain your flab problem. The skinny fat plateau is a huge barrier for a lot of people trying to get thinspo.
DON'T KETO.

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17429852
Get a topical antiviral (a local brand is zovirax, you might have that) and start applying it every day as soon as you feel the cold sore coming (usually the lip gets itchy or stings slightly and it should be in the same spot every time). It won't hide it but it will make it not last as long. Also start taking l-lysine and stop doing whatever it is that triggers it (mine are biting the dead skin on my lips, sleeping poorly and kissing people who also have herpes).

>Any tips or advice on getting into IT man?

Depending on where you're from, the hardest part is getting your foot in the door when it comes to entry level work. Without a degree or some other qualifications, you will find it extremely hard to get an engineering job.

posts.com:
>>17425221
1: If you haven't already, get a vintage bottle of Salvador Dali Pour Homme. Easy to find on eBay, worst case scenario grab a sealed splash bottle and decant into an atomizer. The whole honey tobacco profile for Mugler Pure Havanne/Naxos/18.21 Man Made etc is close to a direct rip from this fragrance. You need the vintage though, which is still cheap. It's also very wearable today, especially since Sauvage Elixir and Beau Du Jour are mainstream.

If you have that go to these next:
Vintage Caron Pour un Homme. Skanky as shit, best kept secret if you like Kouros and Antaeus style frags.
Dior Jules
Dior Eau Sauvage. Vintage 1oz bottles are normally available on eBay.
Vermeil Pour Homme
Maxim's Pour Homme. Another underated classic animalic. Part of me is always greedy and doesn't want to recommend this but it's so good that I have to. Floral,leather, oakmoss, animalic.
Alain Delon Iquitos. The most beautiful fragrance for men I've ever smelled, and it's skanky as hell. Smells hot, tropical, sensual. There's cool history here with Dior rejecting the fragrance and then regretting it, and the frag was discontinued due to ingredient availability rather than reformulate. Get a mini on eBay at least, everyone should smell this one.

I can't stand florals in most men's frags today, the fact that frags like Lyric for Men, Toy Boy and Declaration Soir get pushed as good florals make me shake my head. Florals in the late 70s to early 90s were more common and still MANLY.

Paco Rabanne Tenerre . Similar spirit to Iquitos, different execution. Civet and honey, musk, moss, patchouli and leather with a bouquet on the side. Has a strange dusty vibe which is somehow pleasant.

Azarro Acteur. Leather bomb with a huge blood red rose note, voluptuous and sensual. Great use of nutmeg as well. Somewhat modern smelling too, could be released today as niche and people would go ape shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17425368
2: Paloma Picasso Minotaure. Beautiful fragrance, works flawlessly today. Orange musky creamsickle. Works so well that Almariac decided to be a giant bitch and release the exact same fragrance again and call it Wake Up World but charge niche price. I'm not joking, it's the same fragrance, you can read about it on Fragrantica. save your money, buy a vintage bottle on eBay of the first formulation. Runs 50-70, juice smells fine as long as the box is sealed and unused.

Carlo Corinto for men. Soapy, herbal green leather Fougere with a strong and anachronistic raspberry note. I think Tom Ford got the idea for Tuscan Leather here.

Aramis Havana. Still my favorite tobacco fragrance. Orange,allspice, bay leaf, tobacco, rum and leather. This fragrance just feels passionate and alive. The rerelease isn't bad, but if you want the real deal look for the original blue bottles.

Cappucci Pour Homme. A rougher, more herbal and spicy Acqua Di Parma Colonia


Versace L'homme. Saving the best for last. Pure Italian, perfect mix of class and sleaze. Citrus, musk, leather. Not complicated but executed immaculately, back when Versace was run by the real talent. Easy to find the vintage on eBay, font style is different on the original bottles. Price is low but will skyrocket as supply dwindles.


That's it for now. I've tried to stick with ones that are readily available on eBay for less than $100, Iquitos is the exception but you can still get a mini which will last for years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17425468
I'm actually going through a major Zino phase right now. I bought a small bottle of the vintage last year because of all the Beau de Jour comparisons. I liked it but was also kind of disappointed because I found the opening sour and astringent, and it didn't smell that close to Beau de Jour. And because the bottle I got was so small I was reluctant to wear it much.

Then a few weeks ago I finally bought a bottle of current Zino (along with the deodorant) because it's dirt cheap and I wanted to see how it compared to the vintage. Something clicked when I sprayed it for the first time, and I completely fell in love. It's all I've wanted to wear recently, and I like it even more than Beau de Jour now (I guess this is growing up?). Also the current and vintage are about 90% identical (vintage is a bit stronger, but you can compensate by spraying more).

The opening can still be kind of challenging--intense mouth-watering bergamot and lavender, which can come across as pissy at times. But I think it's gorgeous. Then it dries down into some beautiful dusty patchouli and vanilla, with echoes of rose and geranium, the lavender still humming in the background.

So to answer your question, yes Zino is comfy.

I don't think it's that similar to Z-14. Z-14 is a light woody citrus + cinnamon to my nose, and Zino is darker and heavier (but not oppressively so). You should definitely blind buy Zino if you're at all interested. At this point I'm thinking it's the best value-for-money in all of men's perfumery

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Alright, so here's more about my trip to the city:
>go into large department store
>walk up to Chanel, Dior, Guerlain to test some stuff I've been missing
>quite a few based frags (including Antaeus)
>move on to Byredo, bdk, Initio, diptyque, Bond No. 9, etc. etc. etc.
>everything is basically another take on something I've smelled from Dior, Chanel, Guerlain before
>FUCKING WASTE OF TIME
>only very few outliers
>go to L'Occitane
>Eau des Baux straight up mogs everything that wasn't Dior, Chanel, Guerlain
>go to smaller perfumery
>Cartier a massive disappointment, will never get my rec
>only 3 Nicolai frags, 2 feminine
>Cuir Cuba Intense is ok, but at least different to all the other stuff
>move to The Body Shop
>eh
>Rituals
>eh
>go to niche perfumery
>once AGAIN closed, two hours before their actual closing time (???)
>go to other large department store
>test a few frags
>some designer stuff is once again the best
>Comme des Garcons mogs 90% of all the "niche" stuff
>spent longer sniffing CdG stuff than everything else
>Voyage d'Hermes Parfum is up there too
>Other Hermes stuff still disappoints, won't get my rec
>testers of Toy Boy, Luna Rossa Carbon, and other few interesting ones are empty


And that's it. Check out all the stuff from Dior, Chanel, Guerlain and you've played store fragrances through. CdG is also very interesting, very futuristic and I consider them very wearable, really should go and test only those the next time. Wrists were kinda occupied. Hermes would probably be up there if I liked vetiver, but I don't. Cartier isn't interesting enough, but neither is all the expensive faux-niche shit. It all smells the same. If it has "amber" or "santal" in the name, Guerlain does it better. Tom Ford stuff was unironically the best expensive niche, because it was at least unique from time to time. Nothing which blew me away, though. Had better stuff from MDCI, Tauer, Nicolai etc. which just wasn't available at all these stores.

Why the hate on Red Tobacco? I got a sample of this, then a week later, the day before Christmas eve, I was in downtown Chicago, walking through the long tunnel between Jackson Red and Blue line. >>17429983
Plenty. Iso-E Super smells different to people and smells like nothing at all to some others. Certain ionones can have a really pungent odor while being pleasant to some. I'm not 100% sure but they might be responsible for the dill/pickles smell of Santal 33, if you smell dill/pickles in it. There's a specific molecule which smells completely off to me, but not most people (haven't been able to identify it yet). Benzaldehyde, nitrobenzene and cyanides either smell like almonds or cherries to people (mostly unused in perfumery, just based on my knowledge from the laboratory). A similar effect is represented in Guerlain's L'Homme Ideal (mostly in the EdP), which makes people smell more almond and less cherry or just cherry all the way, for example. I don't get any almond from it and the previously mentioned molecules all smell like cherries to me, despite often being described as also smelling like almonds.

I have three of Iron Heart's ultra heavy weight flannels. I've searched for years for the perfect flannel and have arrived at IH as the end all be all for flannels. The combination of the western button snaps, double brushed interior, and heavy weight of the shirt makes it feel like nothing else. Seriously the most comfortable button up shirt I've ever worn. Not to mention the extreme attention to detail with stitching and the overall structural integrity. On top of all that, these things legitimately look and feel better with each wash. OP, if you decide to cheap out and go with something less expensive, you are doing so knowing that you are buying something that stands in the shadow of what IH produces and you will not be satisfied until you finally just buy one.

posts.name: DougDevious
posts.com:
this brown suit and yellow shirt have finally fulfilled the purpose I bought them for, a wedding of a family member.
I will say, I was not expecting to get as much use out of this brown suit as I did.
I only bought this suit to fit the color palette of the wedding, but with the help of a bulk-lot of 12 shirts and grey suede winklepickers I also bought on eBay, it's served me way better and longer than I was ever expecting it to.

I don't think I'm going to keep it any longer than I have to, since it's a 100% poly-rayon suit with a too-short jacket, but I was still lucky to have it fit as well as it did right out of the box. At this point, to part ways with it, and not have a better quality, better fitting suit in the same shade of brown would leave an awkward gap in my wardrobe. A lot of the shirts I have now would not go as well with say, a navy or grey suit.
Take the brownpill, anons.

Besides the suit, shoes, and shirt, which I bought on eBay, the other pieces I bought specifically for this wedding are in picrel, and all from AliExpress. The bowtie is 100% cotton and probably one of the best I've ever owned.

What do I need to care for my boots?
>Old cotton t shirt (one for cleaning, another for applying conditioners)

>Wooden shoe trees ($10-15)
>Light conditioner like Lexol/Bck4

>mud: allow it to dry then brush off
>salt: water and cloth as soon as possible
>saturated wet: allow the boot to dry for a full day, stuff with newspaper
>scuffs and scratches: buff vigorously with horsehair brush

>Should I buy turdsdays/soloshits/doc shitans?
No they are filled with synthetic materials aimed at instant comfort but will not hold up to actual use.
>b-b-but muh ecelebs on youtube said they're good
no. you will waste your time and money and still have uncomfortable footwear at the end of the day. spend the extra $100 and get something real.

>Vegan

But hey as long as it looks good and shines the way you want it, it doesn't matter if you didn't pay shit for it. Hope this helps, anon good luck.

>>17423659
You're sadly getting left behind a bit. Current trends are showing that a simple necklace plus other simple accessories are rising up.

I do two rings (one per hand, non-married for now [popping the question in a few months, mostly likely]), one with a simple design one with a more complex statement-piece style design. I rotate between ring options from there.

For a bracelet, a simple thin metal cuff works, or beads. But only one beaded bracelet, since more looks a bit tacky and outdated. The goal is to find something that complements your watch on your other wrist: I do the cuff with my metal Orient and a black beaded bracelet for my Invicta Submariner homage. With a NATO strap on the Invicta, it's a solid look that I've gotten complements on.

Don't do the bracelet + watch thing imo, it's not great.

Top all of that off with a simple necklace (sterling silver if pale skin, gold if dark skin) worn under the shirt (so that the metal peeks out every so often rather than all the time), and you're pretty set.

Granted I live in Florida, so accessories have to do a lot of work during hot periods where layering is impossible. Either way, the key is to get simple pieces and not to overdo it. One statement piece is fine, more is pushing it.

based welding thread

I've been welding 3 or 4 years now, it's definitely not effay but it's good honest work for a decent pay - it makes university educated office bitches absolutely sperg out on 4chan for some reason. I think a lot of people end up working in rock-bottom sweatshops welding trailers for $18/hr alongside Pedro and Paco with no respirators and grow to despise it. It's a good career if you take care of your personal health and safety and follow some kind of upward career trajectory instead of killing yourself in some bottom-scraping hellhole. Invest in training and certifications, and focus on enhancing your skill set, and it can be pretty comfy.

Just started my apprenticeship with the UA pipefitters local up in leaf land, before that I was job-hopping for a few years in different fab shops - mostly metal core with some flux core and most recently spic-tier MIG hardwire work (was overpaid, took the money and ran). I have stories, man.

>>17427045
>Is welding a job that pays well enough

Pays enough. Good money means different things to different people but you won't be broke and you'll always have work. It's not rockstar money but it's a living for sure. If you make good career moves, get your red seal (or whatever your equivalent is), specialize in something, and gain a good reputation, you can make low six figures. But that takes years. The better you get the more money you can command, straight up. Nobody is gonna be asking you for references at interviews nor will they give a shit about gaps in your resume. They want to see how good you can weld and how certified you are. Certifications ie "tickets" are EVERYTHING. GET YOUR TICKETS. Get as many tickets as you can muster. Invest heavily in certification. I made 35k-ish my first year, 50-60k my second and third, will be 80k this year - now I am starting an apprenticeship with the pipefitters union, after that - I've heard a lot of stories of guys lining their pockets welding pipe, we shall have to see.

Realize that this board tends to attract the wealthy and 4chan in general attracts all kinds of IT-rich autists so again - good money means different things to different people. If you consider 80k a good income yeah go for it if you're hoping to command top 1% wealth there are better avenues like IT or business management.

>can be enjoyable
As you can see there are tons of people in this thread who did not enjoy welding, and several who did. If you can get the chance, take a short course or something and see if it's for you. I quite like it, and passion will take you everywhere. It's a craft known to burn people out so if you are young and eager you are like gold to employers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
ass pizza did this thing at one point where he would drive around to random parking lots in small towns throughout the midwest. he would just announce a location a few hours in advance and then a ton of people would show up from all the surrounding areas. like crowds of 100+ people. nothing happens in these places and these became like these huge events. he basically took the idea of the supreme lineup and transposed it into random rural environments. the thing about the supreme lineup in NYC is it was never about the clothes it was about the community. it was an excuse for all these kids to leave their house and interact with each other on a weekly basis and make friends and form bonds. ass pizza brought that to the middle of nowhere. that in of itself is genius but the way he did the clothes was even better. he'd pick a walmart or a marks work warehouse and would just tell people to go inside and buy something from levis or carhartt and bring it out. then he would graffiti it on the spot and that random piece of generic mass market workwear is now an ass pizza original that can be flipped on grailed for hundreds of dollars.

the thing is he wouldn't charge people for the clothes they brought him. he would always have a small amount of his own stuff he would bring to make some money to cover his costs but that wasn't really the point here. the point was he's the first person i know who found a way to weaponize the resale market for their brand or at least pull some kind of insane judo move with it. the idea was all the people who came to these events were creative and had ideas of their own they wanted to pursue. if you needed a couple thousand bucks to start something you could go to one of these events, buy an armful of $20 carhartt t-shirts, give them to ass pizza and on the spot he would convert them into $200 carhartt x ass pizza t-shirts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17429997

he knew everyone was flipping this stuff, that was the point. he wanted to give these kids in the middle of nowhere a way out. i don't really know anyone else who's done something like that for their fans and supporters. this is someone weaponizing their brands re-sale value to benefit their own fans. it's really strange but beautiful.

i honestly don't know anyone else in fashion who has done so much with so little. someone who has managed to think so far out the box and do things so completely original with almost nothing. he has no real formal training or even any sort of innate natural talent at anything he does. he's not a good artist or good designer or really a good anything. yet he's come up with completely bizarre and totally original ways of doing things that are unlike anything else that exists in fashion. not talking about design or styling or execution but just purely on ideas: he's on the same level as alexandre mcqueen who also had these sort of radical outside the box way of doing clothes. the thing is mcqueen's venue was runway fashion, ass pizza's is streetwear. so it's easy to write him off but no one else has done more with a graphic t-shirt. i have a deep and profound wish that he one day gets better at actually making and designing clothes so his garments will be able to match the level of his ideas. the good news is you can get better at things like that with time but you cannot become a radical outside the box genius no matter how hard you train, so he already has most people beat in a way that they will never be able to catch up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17429999

i will never forget the kanye west life of pablo merch drop in LA. the designs for the merch leaked a few days beforehand. so the day of the event ass pizza shows up with a huge trailer full of fake copies of the merch except he's added his logo on top. he then began selling them to people waiting in line for the real merch. kanye west himself came out and bought one because of how audacious and hilarious it was. in the process he essentially blessed the fakes transforming them from fake to real. when else has that ever really happened? to this day the ass pizza fakes of that merch are worth more than the originals. i don't know of any other account of that ever happening. this is basically the kind of thing virgil abloh was trying to do or at least claimed he was trying to do when he ripped people off. ass pizza actually did it for real. he ripped someone off in a completely original and meta way that actually made his fake better than the original. virgil abloh with his obsession for duchamp and baudrillard died having never managed to accomplish what ass pizza actually did.

probably my favourite thing he's ever done however was punking supreme. a few years back he announced that he was collaborating with supreme and made a bunch of posts about it thanking them for the opportunity. he then released a supreme t-shirt with three box logos on it. the thing is it wasn't an official collab but ass pizza by this point had become a sort of folk hero to zoomers. as a result he essentially checkmated supreme. this is a company that is all about being aloof and not caring and having an idgaf attitude. that cool cachet is what sells their clothes and keeps their brand relevant. so when ass pizza announced the collab they were left with two choices. denounce the collab or stay silent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17430002

if they denounced it and said it wasn't an official collab ass pizza would have won. supreme would have come off as out of touch butthurt losers. ass pizza basically found all the things supreme would never want to have associated with their brand: being a narc, being lame, being out of touch, being cringe, caring too much, etc. and he used this stuff as a weapon against them and in the process basically gave himself his own legal impunity to not only bootleg their own clothes but do it publicly and thank them for allowing him to do it. supreme never denounced or endorsed the collab and just chose (correctly) to stay totally silent while anyone else on the planet would have been met with immediate litigation.

again i dont know anyone else who has publicly knocked someone off and thanked them for it and gotten away with it. ass pizza is basically the only one. but the setup to pull that off took years of work. so on the one hand its something so incredibly simple and dumb and obvious (make a fake supreme collab) and on the other hand only he could have done it in the way that he did and gotten away with it.

so somehow he's this zoomer with no real talent or education or any kind of real skill whatsoever and everyone thinks he's a moron and yet he's managed to not once but on several occasions do completely original and totally outside the box type galaxy brain moves that have time and time again left me completely inspired and feeling like new ways of doing thats actually can still come about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17430003

so i honestly believe he's one of the greatest living fashion designers alive today. because he's been more original than anyone else i know of. all these designers who talk about championing social justice, ass pizza has actually done it allowing his own fans to eat off his plate, making things specifically for them to flip so they can start their own businesses too. all these designers who talk about being meta and making people think like virgil and demna. neither of those guys have ever made me think with their clothes or actions. ass pizza genuinely has. he's left me thinking deeply about all sorts of weird shit and pondering the meaning of authenticity or celebrity. the circular idea of a celebrity using their own fame to enrich their own fans lives who in turn make them more famous is really fucking weird and interesting. what the hell is actually going on there. it's genuinely meta in a way demna and virgils clothes never have and probably never will be. for designers who speak about doing new things or reaching people in new ways. basically none of the people who claim that ever actually do it. ass pizza really genuinely does do stuff like that. creating a pop up store out of a walmart parking lot in ohio and all the clothes you're selling are actually inside the walmart when you get there is really fucked up. it's like a pop up store where the inventory is procured on site. again its the type of thing demna desperately wishes he could come up with or its the type of thing he believes he's doing. except he's not, ass pizza actually is.

if you slandered his name in this thread you're basically a huge peabrainlet who just doesn't get it. he's the genius, you're the moron. he's also 24 years old, totally insane.

The basics of outdoor clothing is having a functional layering system for the environment you'll be in. As long as you have that you won't be making any sacrifices in comfort nor practicality. I normally wear a polyester base layer, a fleece jacket and an outer shell. Also you could try with mostly muted colours except for one piece of gear, say your middle layer, and have that be something like bright orange or whatever. I think that creates a cool contrast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Long ass post but there's a clothing-related point.
For the winter I bought a merino wool thermal layer for my legs. I found a pair that were 100% merino for a good price. When I unwrapped them, they were literally SO stretchy that I had to re-check the label to make sure they had 0% synthetics. And theyre not itchy at all. After a couple months of wearing the same pair every work day, there's no sign of wear. This is proof that the idea that clothing like socks and underwear absolutely NEED synthetics for durability and stretch is complete BULLSHIT. You don't need to put plastic on your body.

Also, when I was looking for merino socks, I read info on a manufacturer's website that was very enlightening. Their socks were ~40% wool and then 10-20% each of various synthetics. They claimed that this was because the different synthetics all had different qualities that made the perfect sock. Yet It also said that, by US law, wool MUST be the largest single material to market it as wool clothing. So they basically admitted that they use a melange of 4 synthetics just to ensure that wool is still technically the plurality, so they can be legally labeled as merino socks. Another reason not to trust the narrative that synthetics are for performance and not cost-cutting.

>>17424443
You are close to realizing the scale of the operation of shifting accountability for petroleum waste and byproducts from corporations to consumers. Even smaller local companies are just unwitting dupes to facilitate the exchange. Plastic spits in the face of the biological/preternatural creature. "plastic is cheap" is STILL a marketing gimmick. Plastic is quite literally worthless, and, considering it's uniquity, you are being conned paying even a cent for anything made of it. Moreoever, the culture of plastic enabling cheap manufacture has even mutated classically designed garments such that, even when made of 100% natural local materials, they are shaped like something out of a chinese factory, designed by a brain fried homosexual or some borderline lardass woman.

Plastic is cheap enough to be tempting to consumers, and priced at all, to legally justify it's path down the hierarchy quickly, considering that it is already waste this process is outrageous. Soon enough, the end user has a whole house full of literal garbage refashioned into otherwise useless items. Eventually they have to throw their crap away or dispose of it by burning. So they pay twice, once for the inherently defective product, which is an explicitly fiscal exchange, and twice - this time, the cost isn't necessarily monetary - for the inevitable disposal of it. If they pay in money, they pay the municipal council or a contracted private company who have their money circulate back up to where the chain began via the same unwitting dupe nepotism.

You can look at it from so many angles. My favorite is the schizo interpretation, that 'they' who profit off of such an exchange are trying to destroy the world and the quality of the souls thereof. Even in that interpretation you can go for the bataillean view, that such waste is part of the vigor and violence of reality, or the mystical view, that it's a kind of tikkun olam/tempting hand of God.

Our relation to animals is more interesting-I mean to the animals we eat. We adore eating veal, lamb, beef, antelope, pheasant, or grouse, but we don't throw away their "leftovers."
We dress in leather and adorn ourselves with feathers. Like the Chinese, we devour duck without wasting a bit; we eat the whole pig, from head to tail; but we get under these animals' skins as well, in their plumage or in their hide.

Men in clothing live within the animals they devoured. And the same thing for plants. We eat rice, wheat, apples, the divine eggplant, the tender dandelion; but we also weave silk, linen, cotton; we live within the flora as much as we live within the fauna.
We are parasites; thus we clothe ourselves. Thus we live within tents of skins like the gods within their tabernacles. Look at him well-dressed and adorned, magnificent; he shows-he showed-the clean carcass of his host.

Of the soft parasite you can see only the clean-shaven face and the hands, sometimes with out their kid gloves. We parasite each other and live amidst parasites. Which is more or less a way of saying that they constitute our environment.
We live in that black box called the collective; we live by it, on it, and in it. It so happens that this collective was given the form of an animal: Leviathan. We are certainly within something bestial; in more distinguished terms, we are speaking of an organic model for the members of a society.
Our host? I don't know. But I do know that we are within. And that it is dark in there.

M. Serres - The Parasite

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17429059
Don’t listen to that guy anon
Those are flat front trousers, they look pretty straight fit to me. They have a cuff at the hem, and that cuff isn’t done manually it’s actually sewn that way. A pleat isn’t when there’s a visible crease in the front of the leg, it’s when there is excess fabric folded on the front and sewn over when the waistband is applied. It’s to give you more room in the crotch. Again that’s not what is on these trousers. These are just normal grey-blue flat front trousers you can find anywhere. Honestly any cheap department store would have these (probably in a wool blend) but eBay is where you could find a better deal on a used pair, plus it would allow you to try different fits without breaking the bank. There are military surplus pants like this for dirt cheap but those fit pretty bad and come in some unpleasant colors most of the time - pretty easy to tell navy dress blue trousers from normal ones.
Before you buy anything take your best fitting pair of pants and measure them across the waist, knee, and leg opening to get a rough idea of your measurements if you want to buy secondhand.
I can’t stress enough that the pants in your pic do not have pleats on them.

I feel like i have more than enough to make friends here but i dont know how to take the first step.

I feel terrible for never offering help. I think they all passed, the 11 other people left in the class.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I took a picture but did not assume the position.

Color is weird because it's indoors at night.
IRL it looks a bit darker and less yellow, but I haven't seen them in sunlight yet.

My feet are a bit over 28cm by 11cm. I think that makes me like US11.25E (wide) on Brannock.
These are US11E on the Trubalance last which is the biggest/widest/comfiest last Alden has (but the heel is two sizes narrower)

The fit feels exceptional but I would not give final judgment before wearing them at least three times. I like that the toebox is not too tall, there is not a lot of excess height on the vamp. This is rare for my feet. I felt no heel slip at all despite being roomy in the front, also rare.
The last is chunky, it actually protrudes significantly in the big toe area for comfort, but the vamp stitching is a straight line from the laces which hides this fact very well.

The quality of the build feels ok but not special. I am surprised at how rigid the heel stiffener feels, there's no way this is not celastic. Stitching is just okay. It is fully lined. The suede feels ok but not as good as Charles F Stead suede that I also own.

The quality of the finishing is mediocre. The 'storm welt' is a little sloppy but nothing terrible and nothing that would be visible unless closely examined. Stitching is good all around. There was a bit of glue under one of the speedhooks and it has left a small black mark on the suede (visible in the photo on the right boot). I am not going to return them over this, it's high up and on the inside of the boot.

Overall, it's what I thought they would be. Overpriced but you pay for the unique styling. I like it and I hope they are comfy so I can wear them all the time.

Avoid dropping food directly on it.
If it gets a little dirty, use a suede eraser then brush it.
If it gets very dirty, use suede soap, let it dry and brush it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>17429662
Anon are you the EEE guy I was asked to help here >>17429514

What kind of shoes are you looking for?
I have tried a few different brands

It's important to remember that width is also a function of length, a 9.5EEE might feel exactly like a 10E for example.
Before spending money on EEE shoes make sure you're not just buying needlessly short shoes. A lot of people wear shoes that are too small without knowing it.
It will make your life much easier if this was the case, it's easier to just buy larger sizes instead of trying to find EEE widths. And the shoes look better proportioned too.

Anyway I am not really an EEE but I thought I was. I have a pair of EEE 65's from Allen Edmonds and TLB H-Width dress shoes. Those shoes are basically half a size too small and one size too wide for me, but they fit and are generally comfy, although the AE65 instep is too low.

I have Viberg boots in the 2030 last. This is supposed to be an E (wide) but that's fake news. It is narrow in some areas.

I have tried Carmina oxfords in the Rain last. People say it is roomy. It's just a bad last honestly, the heel is massive and the width is narrow. There is Rain EEE but that also makes the heel even bigger.
I have Carmina boots in the Forest last. This one is ok but I should have probably gone with Forest EEE.
Important to remember Carmina "EEE" is not like normal EEE. Their EEE is just one size wider than normal.
If I were to buy Carmina again, I would try the Soller last.

My shell boots are in Bonafe 363mod last. This is a great last for me, very comfy.
My recent buy are Alden Indys in the Trubalance last, E width (one wider than normal). This feels great but have only worn them one day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>transplant
painful, expensive, limited donor hair means a transplant has limitations on the amount of coverage it can restore, have to take fin afterwards so you don't end up needing another transplant 3-4 years down the line

>wig
the good ones are convincing but expensive, you have to live with knowing that you're wearing a wig and the mental stress of hiding that fact from everyone else (and don't give me that shit about how you wouldn't care if everyone knew you were wearing a wig, if you're insecure enough to pay thousands for a hair system, you're also insecure about others finding out that you're using one)

>drugs
only really help you keep what you already have, some people claim regrowth with certain cocktails but everyone's responses are different. you have to maintain the routine constantly, and you risk fucking up your hormones temporarily or permanently. minoxidil also destroys your skin elasticity and ages you

the best theoretical option is hair cloning in which you can get more or less infinite transplants from a small amount of donor hair, but that technology is still "5 years away" (it was 5 years away 5 years ago, as well).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>17426283
Don't. Those ones are not fit for purpose, if they are not pure essential oils or fragrance-grade synthetics you will probably get rashes. Finding the right natural materials is hit and miss, you need to find which ones are good quality, i.e. don't have bad after-smells. It's a good idea to make the aromatic base 80:20 naturals:synthetics (musks, aromachemicals like geraniol, coumarin, beta-ionkne, ethyl vanillin, etc.) for better longevity. Find some good essential oils get some spray bottles (glass, not plastic) and dilute the pure individual oils with ethanol to 10% using a precision, jeweler's scale, and spray them on your skin. If they smell good as the odor develops, you can use them in a fragrance. After that it's a tedious process of experimenting with different ratios. Study which notes are base, middle and top (based on relative longevity) and experiment. Use ethanol as a diluent, you want to aim for about 15% total concentration of the final product.
> What's you recipe
It's mine, you can't have it >:(.

>>17424186
27 y/o. From favorite to least favorite. Eau Extreme, although being the most expensive out of all, was a big disappointment personally, too flowery, very little sillage, when it does die down the tonka smells nice but it doesn’t last nearly as long as my other fragrances. Drakkar Noir is decent, but it really kind of just reminds me of shower gel on steroids. Dry down is a nice musk though. Dylan Blue I consider my “signature scent” I use regularly. First fragrance I bought and I like it because its musky but not aggressive, and is pleasantly sweet. Gotten many compliments on it. Fahrenheit blew my mind, and is hands down my favorite scent out of the four. Its musky and animalistic, but also refined. Massive longevity and sillage. Only reason I don’t wear it daily is because it’s so aggressive. I read a review of it, “sex in a bottle”, that perfectly describes it. Its intimidating and I’m afraid, very afraid.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>17426380
That's all cool, but itchy is itchy bro. You can use the Ultra Purist argument, but if something is straight up uncomfortable even after many wears of breaking it in, then its likely overhyped (especially in the case of Pendleton) and a no go. There are tiers of cotton. I think you're mistaking cotton as being some structurally deficient material that is only used amongst mass producers of fast fashion clothing. Japanese clothing companies almost exclusively use cotton, often times resorting to higher quality cotton in order to make a superior flannel or pair of denim. For example, Iron Heart uses Aspero cotton for their flannels which supposedly is unable to be mass produced and is prized for its high strength, softness, fineness, and volume. Just because something is wool does not indeed make it a superior piece of clothing. Sure, it may breath really well and have a decent structural integrity, but if it doesn't meet the comfort criteria then I cannot imagine justifying paying some of the prices that are often charged for pieces of wool clothing.
